questions.text: Which of the following examples best illustrates competitive inhibition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Methotrexate and Dihydrofolate reductase

Explanation:

Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor molecule resembles the substrate and competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme.It is usually reversible.

 

Competitive inhibitors

clinical correlation

Methotrexate and Dihydrofolate Reductase

Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor by mimicking dihydrofolate, the natural substrate of DHFR, and binding to its active site, thereby preventing dihydrofolate from binding and inhibiting the enzyme's activity.

Sulfa Drugs and PABA

Sulfa drugs, such as sulfanilamide, competitively inhibit the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase by mimicking para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), a substrate involved in folic acid synthesis in bacteria.

Ethanol and Alcohol Dehydrogenase

Ethanol can act as a competitive inhibitor of methanol metabolism by competing for the active site of alcohol dehydrogenase. This is used in cases of methanol poisoning.

Captopril and Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE)

Captopril competes with the natural substrate of ACE, thereby inhibiting the production of angiotensin II, a peptide that increases blood pressure.

 

Cyanide and Cytochrome c Oxidase (Option B): Cyanide and Cytochrome C Oxidase describe non-competitive inhibitions.

 

Alanine and Pyruvate Kinase (Option C): Alanine and Pyruvate Kinase describe non-competitive inhibitions.

 

Citrate and Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) (Option D): Citrate and Phosphofructokinase-1(PFK-1) describes Allosteric Inhibition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false on creatine kinase?

choices.text: Total creatine kinase is estimated in muscular dystrophies
Starts to rise within 3-6 hours of infarction
Increased in hemolysis and congestive heart failure
CK-MB is used as a marker in myocardial infarction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased in hemolysis and congestive heart failure

Explanation:

Creatine kinase is not increased in hemolysis or congestive heart failure

Creatine kinase:

  • Catalyses conversion of creatine phosphate to creatine using ATP
  • Normal value is 15-100 U/L for males and 10-80 U/L for females
  • Starts to rise within 3-6 hours of infarction (Option B)
  • 3 isoenzymes - MM, MB, BB
  • Total CK estimated in muscular dystrophy (Option A)
  • CK-MB estimated in myocardial infarction (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is used to study the kinetics of oligomeric enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hill equation

Explanation:

  • Hill equation relates reaction velocity to substrate concentration in oligomeric enzymes
  • Oligomeric enzymes often exhibit cooperative binding behavior due to their multiple substrate-binding sites
  • They show sigmoidal kinetics

 

Lineweaver-Burk Equation: Michaelis-Menten equation in a linear form (Option A)

 

 

 

Michaelis-Menten Equation (Option B): Relates reaction rate to substrate concentration, might not accurately describe the kinetics of oligomeric enzymes.

 

Dixon Equation (Option D): A method for determining the inhibition constant of an enzyme inhibitor by plotting the inverse of the reaction rate against the inhibitor concentration at different substrate concentrations

questions.text: Which among the following statements regarding the induction and repression of enzymes is NOT true?

choices.text: Repression acts at the gene level to decrease the amount of enzyme
Induction relieves repression on the operator site
ALA(Aminolevulinic acid) synthase is induced by heme

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ALA(Aminolevulinic acid) synthase is induced by heme

Explanation:

  • ALA (Aminolevulinic acid) synthase is induced by barbiturates and repressed by heme
  • Induction and repression of enzymes increase and decrease enzyme biosynthesis respectively at the gene level

Mechanism

Process

Examples

Induction

Relieves repression on the operator site, increasing enzyme biosynthesis (Option B)
  • Lactose-utilizing enzymes in bacteria induced by lactose in the absence of glucose
  • Tryptophan pyrrolase and transaminases induced by glucocorticoids
  • Glucokinase induced by insulin (Option C)
  • ALA (Aminolevulinic acid) synthase induced by barbiturates

Repression

Acts at the gene level, reducing the number of enzyme molecules (Option A)
  • ALA (Aminolevulinic acid) synthase is repressed by heme

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are proteins except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peptidyl transferase

Explanation:

Peptidyl transferase is RNA enzymes/Ribozymes while others are proteins

Ribozymes/RNA enzymes:

Point

Description

Definition

Enzymes made up of RNA

Spliceosomes

Ribozymes + protein components (stabilize the structure of ribozymes)

Examples
  • RNAse-P: generates the ends of tRNAs
  • Peptidyl transferase: Present in ribosomes and used for protein biosynthesis

questions.text: In a Lineweaver-Burk plot for an enzyme experiencing non-competitive inhibition, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot increases, but the y-intercept remains the same.
The y-intercept increases while Km remains constant and the slope increases.
Both the slope and the y-intercept increase.
The slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot decreases while the y-intercept increases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The y-intercept increases while Km remains constant and the slope increases.

Explanation:

Non-competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, which is called an allosteric site. This binding changes the enzyme's shape and reduces its activity, regardless of whether the substrate is present.

 

Effect on the Lineweaver-Burk Plot:

 

The lineweaver burk plot is graphical representation of enzyme kinetics representing Vmax and Km.

  • Effect on Vmax: The y-intercept of the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which represents 1/Vmax increases as Vmax decreases.
  • Effect on Km: The slope of the plot, which is Km/Vmax, remains constant because Km does not change.

 

The y-intercept increases while the Km remains constant for non competitive inhibition.

 

 

Examples of non-competitive inhibitors:

  • Cyanide acts as a non-competitive inhibitor by binding to a site on cytochrome c oxidase that is not the active site, thereby disrupting its function.
  • Fluoride functions as a non-competitive inhibitor by chelating essential metal ions (magnesium or manganese) required for enolase activity, thus inhibiting the enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the changes in Km (Michaelis constant) and Vmax (maximum reaction rate) in the presence of an uncompetitive inhibitor?

choices.text: Km stays the same, Vmax decreases
Km increases, Vmax stays the same

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Km decreases, Vmax decreases

Explanation:

Uncompetitive Inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing it from converting the substrate into product. This type of inhibition results in:

  • Decrease in Km : Since the inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, it effectively lowers the concentration of the enzyme available for reaction, making the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate appear higher
  • Decrease in Vmax : The inhibitor reduces the maximum rate of reaction because it prevents the enzyme-substrate complex from proceeding to form the product, thus lowering the overall reaction rate at saturating substrate concentrations.

 

 

Therefore, in Uncompetitive Inhibition, both Km and Vmax decrease.

 

Examples of Uncompetitive inhibition:

 

Uncompetitive inhibitors

Clinical correlation

Lithium and Inositol Monophosphatase

This inhibition disrupts the phosphatidylinositol signaling pathway, which is important in mood regulation, making lithium effective in treating bipolar disorder.

Phenylalanine and Alkaline Phosphatase

It binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, reducing the enzyme's activity. This mechanism is studied in the context of metabolic disorders involving phenylalanine.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding enzymes?

a) Enzymes are proteins that can accelerate reactions by factors of 10^6 to 10^9 or more.

b) Enzymes act on a wide range of substrates.

c) Enzymes stabilize the ground state.

d) Enzymes can catalyze both forward and reverse reactions. their

e) Enzymes are regulated by pH, temperature, inhibitors, and activators.

f) Enzyme are water insoluble
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) a, d, e

Explanation:

Properties of Enzyme

Nature of Enzymes

Enzymes are proteins, heat-sensitive, water-soluble. (Statement f ruled out)

Efficiency

Enzymes can accelerate reactions by factors 106 to 109 or more. (Statement a)

Specificity

Enzymes act on specific substrates and can distinguish stereoisomers. (Statement b ruled out)

Cofactors/Coenzymes

Some enzymes need non-protein molecules (cofactors or coenzymes) to be active.

Substrate Binding

Enzymes bind substrates at multiple points, creating chiral products from non-chiral substrates.

Transition State

Enzymes stabilize the transition state, lowering activation energy. (Statement c ruled out)

Reversibility

Enzymes can catalyze both forward and reverse reactions. (Statement d)

Regulation

Activity is regulated by pH, temperature, inhibitors, and activators. (Statement e)

questions.text:
Given the following enzyme kinetics parameters:


	Maximum velocity (Vmax): 100 µmol/min
	Michaelis constant (Km): 10 µM
	Initial velocity (Vo): 50 µmol/min


What is the substrate concentration [S] of the given enzyme?
questions.solution:
The substrate concentration [S] represents the amount of substrate available for the enzyme to act upon in a given reaction. It is typically measured in units of concentration, such as micromoles per liter (µM) or millimoles per liter (mM).

 

To find the substrate concentration [S], you can use the Michaelis-Menten equation:

 

Vo = Vmax[S]/Km + [S]

 

Given:

(Vmax): 100 µmol/min

(Km): 10 µM

(Vo): 50 µmol/min

 

Substitute the given values into the equation:

 

50 = 100[S]/10+ [S]

 

50 (10 + [S]) = 100 [S]

 

Simplify and solve for [S]:

 

500 + 50[S] = 100[S]

 

500 = 50[S]

 

[S] = 10 µM

 

Therefore, the substrate concentration [S] is 10 µM.

questions.text: In enzyme kinetics, a double reciprocal plot (Lineweaver-Burk plot) is used to determine kinetic parameters. What do the x-intercept and y-intercept of a double reciprocal plot represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) x-intercept: -1/Km; y-intercept: 1/Vmax

Explanation:

  • Double reciprocal plots typically are used both to distinguish between competitive and non-competitive inhibitors and to simplify evaluation of inhibition constants.
  • The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal plot used to linearize the Michaelis-Menten equation. The Michaelis-Menten equation is:

 

V = Vmax[S]/Km + [S]

 

Taking the reciprocal of both sides, we get the Lineweaver-Burk equation:

 

1/V = Km/Vmax[S] + 1/Vmax

 

In this linear form, plotting 1/V(y-axis) against 1/[S] (x-axis) yields a straight line.

 

The x-intercept of this plot is -1/Km and the y-intercept is 1/Vmax.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Michaelis Menten equation is true?

choices.text: Used to calculate the rate of reaction
Substrate concentration is required to calculate the rate using Michaelis Menten equation
Michaelis constant is the substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All are true

Explanation:

Michalis Menten equation:

V = Vmax x S / (Km + S)

Where,

V = Velocity of reaction

Vmax = Maximum velocity of the reaction

S = Substrate concentration

Km = Michaelis constant = Substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2)

questions.text: What is the correct equation to calculate the catalytic efficiency of an enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kcat / Km

Explanation:

The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is the ratio of Kcat to Km

Catalytic Efficiency = Kcat / Km

Where,

  • Kcat = Catalytic constant = The catalytic activity of homogeneous enzyme = Ratio of the maximum velocity of the reaction to the number of active sites on the enzymes

Kcat=Vmax / St

  • Km = Michalis constant = Substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity (Vmax / 2)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false


	Increase in enzyme concentration increases the rate of reaction
	Increase in substrate concentration increases the rate of reaction
	Increase in product concentration increases the rate of reaction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3

Explanation:

Increased product concentration slows, stops, or reverses the reaction

Factor

Effect on Reaction Rate

Enzyme Concentration
  • Rate of reaction increases with an increase in enzyme concentration

 

Substrate Concentration
  • Initial phases: Velocity increases with increasing substrate concentration
  • Vmax: Maximum velocity attainable at substrate saturation level
  • Once Vmax is attained, changes in substrate concentration will not affect the rate of reaction

 

Product Concentration
  • Increased product concentration slows, stops, or reverses the reaction

 

Temperature
  • Increasing temperature increases reaction velocity
  • Velocity reaches a maximum at an optimum temperature and then falls with further increase

 

pH
  • Each enzyme has an optimum pH
  • pH value is nearer to optimum→reaction rate increases

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true regarding the mechanisms of action of enzymes?


	Enzymes that act by altering the strain of substrates catalyze lytic reactions
	Enzymes forming covalent bonds are seen commonly in group transfer reactions
	When the functional groups of aminoacyl side chains of enzymes act as an acid or base, the rate of reaction increases
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3

Explanation:

Different enzymes have different mechanisms to catalyze a reaction

Mechanism

Description

Catalysis by Proximity

Substrates come in bond-forming proximity to enzymes→Enzymes bind substrate molecules at their active site→region of high local substrate concentration created→substates are ideally positioned to chemically interact→reaction is catalyzed

Acid-Base Catalysis

Ionizable functional groups of aminoacyl side chains and prosthetic groups of enzymes act as acids or bases causing catalysis (Statement 3)

Catalysis by Strain

Enzymes bind substrates in a conformation that weakens the bond targeted for cleavage→ catalyses lytic reactions (Statement 1)

Covalent Catalysis
  • Formation of a covalent bond between the enzyme and one or more substrates catalyzes the reaction
  • Common among enzymes that catalyze group transfer reactions (Statement 2)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatty stools complains that her symptoms worsen after a high-fat meal. Reduced activity of pancreatic lipase is suspected. Which of the following ions is most likely to be low in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calcium

Explanation:

Pancreatic lipase is an ion-activated enzyme. Its activity is enhanced by adding calcium ions, which is its cofactor.

  • A cofactor is a collective term that includes coenzymes and metal ions
  • Enzymes that require certain metal ions for their activity are called metalloenzymes

Metal-ion (cofactor)

Enzymes

Calcium (Option A)

Lecithinase, lipase

Copper (Option B)

Tyrosinase, cytochrome oxidase, superoxide dismutase

Iron (Option C)

Cytochrome oxidase, catalase, peroxidase, xanthine oxidase

Zinc (Option D)

Carbonic anhydrase, carboxypeptidase, alcohol dehydrogenase

Magnesium

Hexokinase, enolase, glucose-6-phosphatase

Manganese

Phosphoglucomutase, glycosyl transferases

Molybdenum

Xanthine oxidase

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and muscle weakness. Laboratory tests indicate a deficiency in riboflavin. Which coenzyme's function is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FAD

Explanation:

 

FAD is derived from riboflavin and is essential for redox reactions in the electron transport chain.

 

Coenzyme Type

Source (Vitamin)

Function

Example Reaction

NAD/NADP (Option A)

Nicotinamide (B3)

Redox reactions

Cellular respiration

FAD / FM (Option B)

Riboflavin (B2)

Redox reactions

Electron transport chain

Coenzyme A (Option C)

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Acyl group transfer

Fatty acid metabolism

Folic acid/ Cobamide (Option D)

Folate (B9), B12

One-carbon metabolism

DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of prosthetic groups?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Protein degradation

Explanation

 

Prosthetic groups

Definition
  • Non-protein molecules tightly bound to proteins via covalent or non-covalent bonds.
  • Essential for enzyme catalytic activity.

Examples
  • Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Amino acid metabolism.
  • Flavin Mononucleotide (FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD): Redox reactions.
  • Thiamin Pyrophosphate (TPP): Decarboxylation reactions.

Functions
  • Substrate Binding and Orientation: Proper orientation of substrates for catalytic reaction. (Option A)
  • Formation of Covalent Bonds: Covalent bonds with reaction intermediates. (Option B)
  • Electron Transfer: Facilitates electron transfer in redox reactions. (Option C)
  • Activation of Substrates: Acts as Lewis acids or bases to enhance substrate reactivity.

Characteristics
  • Stable Incorporation: Tightly bound to enzymes, unlike transient cofactors.
  • Role in Catalysis: Enhance enzyme capabilities beyond amino acid side chains.
  • Versatility: Involved in various reactions like oxidation-reduction, group transfer, covalent bond formation.

questions.text:
Match the enzyme class with its corresponding example:

 


	
		
			
			Enzyme Class
			
			
			Example
			
		
		
			
			A) Oxidoreductases
			
			
			1) Hexokinase
			
		
		
			
			B) Transferases

			C) Hydrolases
			
			
			3) DNA ligase
			
		
		
			
			D) Lyases
			
			
			4) Trypsin
			
		
		
			
			E) Isomerases
			
			
			5) Aldolase
			
		
		
			
			F) Ligases
			
			
			6) Triosephosphate isomerase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-5, E-6, F-3

Explanation:

 

Class

Function

Examples

Oxidoreductases

Catalyze oxidation-reduction reactions

Lactate dehydrogenase, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

Transferases

Transfer functional groups

Hexokinase, aminotransferase

Hydrolases

Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of bonds

Trypsin, acetylcholine esterase

Lyases

Cleave bonds by means other than hydrolysis/oxidation

Aldolase, decarboxylases

Isomerases

Join two molecules, using ATP

DNA ligase, acetyl-CoA synthetase

questions.text: What is the role of activation energy in a chemical reaction, and how do enzymes influence it?

choices.text: Activation energy converts molecules from transition to ground state; enzymes increase it.
Activation energy converts molecules from ground state to transition state; enzymes lower it.
Activation energy is released during product formation; enzymes do not affect it.
Activation energy breaks bonds in products; enzymes increase it.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Activation energy converts molecules from ground state to transition state; enzymes lower it.

Explanation

 

                                               Activation energy

Definition
  • Activation energy is the energy required to convert molecules from the ground state to the transition state (An unstable intermediate with partially formed and broken bonds.
  • Activation energy is a barrier that must be overcome for a reaction to proceed; typically positive, indicating an energy requirement.

Role of Enzymes

Enzymes lower activation energy, making it easier for reactions to occur.

Reaction Rate Factors

Reaction rate increases as activation energy decreases; temperature increases kinetic energy, leading to more frequent and energetic collisions.

Visualization

Transition state visualized as neither free substrate nor product, with partial bonds forming and rupturing.

Substrate Binding

Enzymes optimize weak interactions with substrates, providing the driving force for catalysis.

Influencing Factors

Enzyme activity is affected by pH, temperature, and presence of inhibitors or activators.

Example

Acid hydrolysis of sucrose: Activation energy with enzyme (sucrase) is 9,000 cal/mol while without enzyme is around 26,000 cal/mol.

Activation energy converts molecules from transition to ground state; enzymes increase it (Option A):

  • This reverses the direction of the energy process.

  • Activation energy is required to reach the transition state, not to return to the ground state.

  • Also, enzymes do not increase activation energy, they lower it to speed up the reaction.

  • So this statement is incorrect in both concept and mechanism.


 

Activation energy is released during product formation; enzymes do not affect it (Option C):

  • Activation energy is absorbed, not released, it’s the energy needed to start the reaction, not something that comes out of it.

  • Energy may be released or absorbed during product formation, depending on whether the reaction is exergonic or endergonic, but that’s not the same as activation energy.

  • Moreover, enzymes do affect activation energy, they lower it, which is a key feature of catalysis.

  • So this option is wrong in both defining activation energy and the role of enzymes.



 

Activation energy breaks bonds in products; enzymes increase it (Option D):

  • Activation energy is needed to break bonds in the reactants to allow them to form the products, not the other way around.

  • Also, enzymes do not increase activation energy, their purpose is to lower it, making reactions faster and more efficient.

  • So this option incorrectly identifies both the target of activation energy and the role of enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about suicide inhibition is incorrect?

choices.text: The inhibitor covalently binds to the enzyme after being converted to a reactive intermediate.
Suicide inhibition is a reversible form of enzyme inhibition.
Suicide inhibitors resemble the enzyme's natural substrate.
Allopurinol acts as a suicide inhibitor of xanthine oxidase to manage gout.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suicide inhibition is a reversible form of enzyme inhibition.

Explanation:

Suicide inhibition, is a special type of irreversible enzyme inhibition.

 

Process of Suicide Inhibition:

 

Examples of Suicide Inhibition:

 

Enzyme

Inhibitor

Mechanism

Clinical Application

Ornithine Decarboxylase (ODC)

Difluoromethylornithine (DFMO)

DFMO binds to ODC, is converted to a reactive form, and irreversibly inactivates the enzyme.

Treats trypanosomiasis by stopping polyamine synthesis in Trypanosoma parasites.

Xanthine Oxidase (Option D)

Allopurinol

Allopurinol is oxidized to alloxanthine, which forms an irreversible complex with xanthine oxidase.

Manages gout by reducing uric acid levels.

Cyclo-oxygenase (COX)

Aspirin

Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in COX, irreversibly inhibiting the enzyme.

Reduces inflammation and pain, and prevents heart attacks and strokes.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical reactions is not regulated by allosteric regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucokinase in glycolysis

Explanation:

Glucokinase catalyzes the first step of glycolysis, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. Unlike some other enzymes, glucokinase is primarily regulated by product inhibition (glucose-6-phosphate) rather than allosteric regulation.

 

  • Allosteric regulation is a mechanism where an enzyme's activity is modified by the binding of an effector molecule at a site other than the active site, known as the allosteric site.
  • Allosteric Site: A specific location on an enzyme distinct from the active site where effector molecules bind, inducing conformational changes that influence enzyme activity.
  • Effectors: Molecules that bind to the allosteric site and modify enzyme activity.
  • Conformational Changes: Binding of an effector to the allosteric site causes a conformational change in the enzyme, which can alter the enzyme's affinity for its substrate and modify the enzyme's catalytic efficiency.

 

Examples of Allosteric Regulation

Enzyme

Allosteric Inhibitor

Allosteric Activator

Notes

Phosphofructokinase (Option A)

ATP, citrate

AMP, F-2,6-P

Key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis

Aspartate transcarbamoylase (Option B)

CTP

ATP

Important in pyrimidine synthesis

Glycogen phosphorylase (Option C)

ATP, glucose-6-P

AMP

Regulates glycogen breakdown

Pyruvate kinase

ATP, alanine

F-1,6-BP

Regulates glycolysis

questions.text: Which of the following shapes of the Michaelis-Menten plot is observed for allosteric regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sigmoidal curve

 

Explanation:

A sigmoidal curve, typical of allosteric enzymes, shows cooperative binding. Initially, reaction velocity rises slowly due to low substrate affinity. As more substrates bind, conformational changes enhance enzyme affinity, causing a sharp increase in velocity before saturation.

 

In enzyme kinetics, a hyperbolic curve in Michaelis-Menten plots represents enzymes with simple kinetics, where reaction velocity increases rapidly at low substrate concentrations and levels off as the enzyme becomes saturated.

questions.text:
Match the following regulation mechanisms with their respective enzymatic reactions:


	
		
			
			Regulation mechanisms
			
			
			Enzymatic reactions
			
		
		
			
			1. Compartmentation
			
			
			a. Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase
			
		
		
			
			2. Feedback inhibition
			
			
			b. Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP
			
		
		
			
			3. Covalent modification
			
			
			c. Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol
			
		
		
			
			4. Proteolytic activation
			
			
			d. Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 - c, 2 - b, 3 - a, 4 - d

 

Explanation:

 

Regulation mechanisms

Enzymatic reactions

1. Compartmentation

c. Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol

2. Feedback inhibition

b. Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP

3. Covalent modification

a. Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase

4. Proteolytic activation

d. Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin


 

Regulatory Mechanism

Description

Examples

Compartmentation

Separating metabolic processes into different cellular compartments to regulate their activity.
  • Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol.
  • Separation of fatty acid oxidation in the mitochondria from fatty acid synthesis in the cytosol.

Feedback Inhibition

A molecule decreases the activity of an enzyme.
  • Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP.
  • Inhibition of acetyl-CoA carboxylase by palmitoyl-CoA in fatty acid synthesis.

Covalent Modification

Addition or removal of a covalent bond of a chemical group to alter an enzyme's activity.
  • Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Acetylation of histones affecting gene expression.

Proteolytic Activation

Converting an inactive enzyme precursor into its active form through proteolytic cleavage.
  • Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin.
  • Activation of trypsinogen to trypsin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about isoenzymes is incorrect?

choices.text: Isoenzymes can be distinguished by their different amino acid sequences or structural properties
Allozymes are produced by different genes and can have distinct Km values or substrate affinities
Isoforms result from post-translational modifications, such as changes in sialic acid content in alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
Electrophoresis is a technique used to separate isoenzymes based on their mobility.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Allozymes are produced by different genes and can have distinct Km values or substrate affinities

 

Explanation:

Allozymes are variants of the same gene, not produced by different genes. They do exhibit differences in Km values or substrate affinities.

 

Isoenzymes

  • Isoenzymes or isozymes, are distinct forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same chemical reaction but differ in their amino acid sequences, structural properties, or regulatory mechanisms (Option A)
  • These variations allow isoenzymes to be tissue-specific or associated with different developmental stages, reflecting their adaptation to specific physiological needs or conditions while performing the same fundamental biochemical function.

 

Variants:

True Isoenzymes: Produced by different genes, e.g., salivary vs. pancreatic amylase.

Allozymes: Variants of the same gene, e.g., glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase 

Isoforms: Result from post-translational modifications, e.g., sialic acid content in ALP (Option C)

 

Identification Techniques:

  • Electrophoresis: Isoenzymes can be separated based on mobility (Option D)
  • Heat Stability: Some isoenzymes are more heat-sensitive.
  • Inhibitors: Sensitivity to specific inhibitors can help differentiate isoenzymes.
  • Km Value/Substrate Specificity: Different isoenzymes may have distinct Km values or substrate affinities.
  • Cofactor Requirements: Isoenzymes might differ in their cofactor needs.
  • Tissue Localization: Isoenzymes are often found in specific tissues.

 

Examples:

  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH): 5 isoforms (LDH-1 to LDH-5)
  • Creatine Kinase (CK): 3 isoforms (CK-MM, CK-BB, CK-MB)
  • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP): 3 isoforms (Bone, Liver, Placental)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe pain and swelling in his right calf following an intense workout session two days ago. Laboratory tests, including measurements of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzymes, are ordered. Which LDH isoenzyme is most indicative of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) LDH-5

Explanation:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme involved in converting lactate to pyruvate during anaerobic glycolysis.
  • It consists of four subunits, forming five different isoenzymes that vary in tissue distribution.
  • LDH-5, primarily found in skeletal muscle and liver, serves as a biomarker and typically indicates skeletal muscle damage, seen in muscle injury, rhabdomyolysis, or intense physical exertion.

 

Isoenzyme

Tissue/Organ

Clinical Use

LDH-1(Option A)

Heart

Elevated levels can indicate myocardial infarction or other tissue damage.

LDH-2 (Option B)

Reticuloendothelial system

Elevated levels can suggest tissue damage or disease.

LDH-3 (Option C)

Lungs

Elevated levels can be associated with lung conditions.

LDH-4

Kidneys and placenta

Elevated levels may indicate kidney or placental issues.

LDH-5

Liver and skeletal muscle

Elevated levels can be related to liver or muscle damage.
